awd_titl_txt: Research Infrastructure: Support for a Workshop on Artificial Intelligence to Assist Mathematical Reasoning
awd_abstract_narration:
This award supports the organization of a 2-day Workshop on Artificial Intelligence to Assist Mathematical Reasoning in May 2023. This workshop brings together academic, industry, and government stakeholders to discuss the 

(1) state of the art of using AI to assist mathematical reasoning, including case studies in particular domains; 
(2) opportunities to advance research in AI for mathematical reasoning and potential impacts from doing so, and technical advances required to expand this initiative; 
(3) current challenges and barriers to the use of AI for mathematical reasoning; and 
(4) roles for stakeholders in advancing AI for mathematical reasoning. 

Workshop videos and presentations will be posted online and a professional science writer will author a short workshop proceeding reflecting the key points from the workshop.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The National Academies of Sciences, Engineering, and Medicine hosted a public workshop that brought together academic, industry, and government stakeholders to discuss the state of the art, current challenges, and opportunities to advance research in using AI for mathematical reasoning, encompassing the use of AI for mathematical discovery and for theorem proving. The workshop was held virtually over three days from June 12-14, 2023, and recordings as well as proceedings summarizing the workshop are available on the project site. The project also hosted a public dissemination webinar for the workshop proceedings on September 26, 2023, and a follow-on webinar series in April 2024 that focused on specific topics discussed during the workshop: proof assistants, machine learning approaches to mathematical discovery, and the future of collaboration. 

The workshop and following webinars brought together domain experts from mathematics, statistics, computer science, data science, and other relevant fields; highlighted emerging research opportunities; and explored approaches to strengthen coordination and collaboration among the interdisciplinary research communities. By bringing together mathematicians, computer scientists, and other researchers from various areas that all have common threads in AI to assist mathematical reasoning, the workshop and following webinars opened doors for cross-disciplinary work that is vital to further the field.  

Students and early career professionals were among the many viewers who attended the virtual workshop, and the workshop served to spread awareness and share resources on how viewers could become more involved in automated theorem proving and formalizing mathematics. The workshop and webinars encouraged mathematics students and early career professionals to become involved in automated theorem proving and seek education on AI technologies more broadly, as well as encouraged traditional mathematics teachers and professors to adopt these tools and educate their students in the area. 

The workshop, its proceedings, and the webinars were widely advertised through channels including email lists for the National Academies’ Board on Mathematical Sciences and Analytics and the Computer Science and Telecommunications Board ; social media posts and advertising; email marketing to readers of past mathematical reports from the National Academies via the National Academy Press; and advertising through committee members and workshop participants.

By furthering the conversation, the workshop and webinars contributed to advancing AI for mathematical reasoning, and further developments in the field may have significant implications for advancing other research areas. Notably, advances could accelerate scientific discovery by automating the process of generating and verifying hypotheses, analyzing data, and discovering patterns in complex systems. This may lead to breakthroughs in fields such as physics, biology, chemistry, and materials science. Ultimately, there may be far-reaching implications across various areas, leading to improving technological innovation, enhancing healthcare outcomes, informing policy decisions, transforming education, advancing the capabilities of autonomous systems, and beyond.
